intent_atoms.description: Implement manifest-driven remote fixture acquisition so generate_fixtures.py can download, verify, and catalog large media assets required for benchmarking and validation.
generate_fixtures.py accepts a manifest describing remote assets, downloads each entry, verifies SHA-256 checksums, and writes deterministic filenames under the documented storage structure.
The script copies or references license texts for each source into Documentation/FixtureCatalog/licenses/ so redistribution requirements are met.
A tracked manifest (e.g., Documentation/FixtureCatalog/manifest.json) records URLs, checksums, coverage tags, and license references for CI/hardware runners.
Script output logs clearly indicate download status, verification results, and storage paths to aid future automation and troubleshooting.
The script must always verify SHA-256 checksums of downloaded assets before accepting them.

Extend the Python script with a manifest loader, streaming download helpers (with resume-friendly temp files), and checksum validation; reuse existing fixture catalog patterns for deterministic naming.
Mirror each source license into a dedicated directory and link it from the manifest entry to satisfy attribution requirements before bundling fixtures with runners.

Stage large assets outside the test bundle under Distribution/Fixtures/ while keeping lightweight regression assets in-repo; document mount paths in the follow-up README task to align with storage guidance.
Consider adding a dry-run mode that validates checksums and license availability without downloading to support CI gating.
